20110126032102.000|20110126032104.000|TR0|movingly at a memorial event for the six

20110126032144.000|20110126032147.000|TR0|
20110126032147.000|20110126032149.000|TR0|Tonight, the president focused a lot of 
20110126032149.000|20110126032152.000|TR0|attention on our economy in general, and 
20110126032152.000|20110126032154.000|TR0|on our deficit and debt in particular.  He 
20110126032154.000|20110126032157.000|TR0|was right to do so, and some of his words 
20110126032157.000|20110126032159.000|TR0|were reassuring.  As chairman of the House 
20110126032159.000|20110126032202.000|TR0|Budget Committee, I assure you that we 
20110126032202.000|20110126032204.000|TR0|want to work with the president to 
20110126032204.000|20110126032207.000|TR0|restrain federal spending.
20110126032207.000|20110126032209.000|TR0|
20110126032209.000|20110126032212.000|TR0|In one of our first acts in the new 
20110126032212.000|20110126032214.000|TR0|majority, House Republicans voted to cut 
20110126032214.000|20110126032217.000|TR0|Congress's own budget.  And just today, 
20110126032217.000|20110126032219.000|TR0|the House voted to restore the spending 
20110126032219.000|20110126032222.000|TR0|discipline that Washington sorely needs.
20110126032222.000|20110126032224.000|TR0|
20110126032224.000|20110126032227.000|TR0|The reason is simple.  A few years ago, 
20110126032227.000|20110126032229.000|TR0|reducing spending was important.  Today, 
20110126032229.000|20110126032232.000|TR0|it's imperative.  Here's why.
20110126032232.000|20110126032234.000|TR0|
20110126032234.000|20110126032237.000|TR0|We face a crushing burden of debt.  The 
20110126032237.000|20110126032239.000|TR0|debt will soon eclipse our entire economy 
20110126032239.000|20110126032242.000|TR0|and grow to catastrophic levels in the 
20110126032242.000|20110126032244.000|TR0|years ahead.
20110126032244.000|20110126032247.000|TR0|
20110126032247.000|20110126032250.000|TR0|On this current path, when my three 
20110126032250.000|20110126032252.000|TR0|children -- who are now six, seven, and 
20110126032252.000|20110126032255.000|TR0|eight years old -- are raising their own 
20110126032255.000|20110126032257.000|TR0|children, the federal government will 
20110126032257.000|20110126032300.000|TR0|double in size, and so will the taxes they 
20110126032300.000|20110126032302.000|TR0|pay.
20110126032302.000|20110126032305.000|TR0|
20110126032305.000|20110126032307.000|TR0|No economy can sustain such high levels of 
20110126032307.000|20110126032310.000|TR0|debt and taxation. The next generation 
20110126032310.000|20110126032312.000|TR0|will inherit a stagnant economy and a 
20110126032312.000|20110126032315.000|TR0|diminished country.  Frankly, it's one of 
20110126032315.000|20110126032317.000|TR0|my greatest concerns as a parent, and I 
20110126032317.000|20110126032320.000|TR0|know many of you feel the same way.
20110126032320.000|20110126032322.000|TR0|
20110126032322.000|20110126032325.000|TR0|Our debt is the product of acts by many 
20110126032325.000|20110126032327.000|TR0|presidents and many Congresses over many 
20110126032327.000|20110126032330.000|TR0|years.  No one person or party is 
20110126032330.000|20110126032332.000|TR0|responsible for it.
20110126032332.000|20110126032335.000|TR0|
20110126032335.000|20110126032337.000|TR0|There's no doubt the president came into 
20110126032337.000|20110126032340.000|TR0|office facing a severe fiscal and economic 
20110126032340.000|20110126032342.000|TR0|situation.  Unfortunately, instead of 
20110126032342.000|20110126032345.000|TR0|restoring the fundamentals of economic 
20110126032345.000|20110126032347.000|TR0|growth, he engaged in a stimulus spending 
20110126032347.000|20110126032350.000|TR0|spree that not only failed to deliver on 
20110126032350.000|20110126032352.000|TR0|his promise to create jobs, but also 
20110126032352.000|20110126032355.000|TR0|plunged us even deeper into debt.
20110126032355.000|20110126032357.000|TR0|
20110126032357.000|20110126032400.000|TR0|The facts are clear:  Since taking office, 
20110126032400.000|20110126032402.000|TR0|President Obama has signed into law 
20110126032402.000|20110126032405.000|TR0|spending increases of nearly 25 percent

20110126032422.000|20110126032425.000|TR0|percent, and government has added over $3

20110126034640.000|20110126034643.000|TR0|

20110126034645.000|20110126034648.000|TR0|in our national conversation, and it's an 
20110126034648.000|20110126034650.000|TR0|honor for me to speak with you.       Two 
20110126034650.000|20110126034653.000|TR0|years ago, when Barack Obama became our 
20110126034653.000|20110126034655.000|TR0|president, unemployment was 7.8 percent, 
20110126034655.000|20110126034658.000|TR0|and our national debt stood at what seemed 
20110126034658.000|20110126034700.000|TR0|like a staggering $10.6 trillion.  We 
20110126034700.000|20110126034703.000|TR0|wondered whether the president would cut 
20110126034703.000|20110126034705.000|TR0|spending, reduce the deficit, and 
20110126034705.000|20110126034708.000|TR0|implement real job-creating policies.
20110126034708.000|20110126034710.000|TR0|

20110126034713.000|20110126034715.000|TR0|for recovery was to spend a trillion

20110126034720.000|20110126034723.000|TR0|promised us that all the spending would 
20110126034723.000|20110126034725.000|TR0|keep unemployment under 8 percent.  Well, 
20110126034725.000|20110126034728.000|TR0|not only did that plan fail to deliver, 
20110126034728.000|20110126034731.000|TR0|but within three months, the national 
20110126034731.000|20110126034733.000|TR0|jobless rate spiked to 9.4 percent.  It 
20110126034733.000|20110126034736.000|TR0|hasn't been lower for 20 straight months.
20110126034736.000|20110126034738.000|TR0|
20110126034738.000|20110126034741.000|TR0|While the government grew, we lost more 
20110126034741.000|20110126034743.000|TR0|than 2 million jobs.
20110126034743.000|20110126034746.000|TR0|
20110126034746.000|20110126034748.000|TR0|Let me show you a chart.  Here are 
20110126034748.000|20110126034751.000|TR0|unemployment rates over the past ten 
20110126034751.000|20110126034753.000|TR0|years.  In October of 2001, our national 
20110126034753.000|20110126034756.000|TR0|unemployment rate was at 5.3 percent.  In 
20110126034756.000|20110126034758.000|TR0|2008, it was at 6.6 percent.  But just 
20110126034758.000|20110126034801.000|TR0|eight months after President Obama 
20110126034801.000|20110126034803.000|TR0|promised lower unemployment, that rate 
20110126034803.000|20110126034806.000|TR0|spiked to a staggering 10.1 percent.
20110126034806.000|20110126034808.000|TR0|
20110126034808.000|20110126034811.000|TR0|Today, unemployment is at 9.4 percent with 
20110126034811.000|20110126034813.000|TR0|about 400,000 new claims every week.
20110126034813.000|20110126034816.000|TR0|
20110126034816.000|20110126034818.000|TR0|After the $700 billion bailout, the 
20110126034818.000|20110126034821.000|TR0|trillion-dollar stimulus, and the massive 
20110126034821.000|20110126034823.000|TR0|budget bill with over 9,000 earmarks, many 
20110126034823.000|20110126034826.000|TR0|of you implored Washington to please stop

20110126034828.000|20110126034831.000|TR0|of cutting, we saw an unprecedented 
20110126034831.000|20110126034833.000|TR0|explosion of government spending and debt.

20110126034843.000|20110126034846.000|TR0|under President Bush, but they exploded
